question.title: Selenium Java Actions vs Webelement.click()
question.body:
I was performing a simple user action on Amazon Website. Launch Amazon India WebPage >> Clicked on HamBurger Menu >> Clicked On Fire TV >> Click on Amazon Prime Video

While I was performing click on 'Amazon Prime Video' using WebElement.click(), it is not working, whether i use Thread.sleep(), or explicit wait. So I thought to use Actions class,and it is working fine with that.

My doubt is why it is so??...as I am performing click on a normal button like webelement,where no mouse hover is required..

2nd issue is if I Use locator linktext for 'Amazon Prime Video' it is failing even with Actions class, but using xpath = "//a[text()='Amazon Prime Video']", it is working fine. But I as per my knowledge ,both are same,so it should work in both cases..

The sample code is here....

public class AmazonWebPageActions {
            WebDriver driver = new EdgeDriver();
            @Test
            public void testingMini() throws InterruptedException {
                driver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(Duration.ofSeconds(10));
                driver.get("https://www.amazon.in/");
                driver.findElement(By.xpath("//i[@class=\"hm-icon nav-sprite\"]")).click();
                Thread.sleep(2000);
                WebElement fireTv = driver.findElement(By.xpath("//div[text()='Fire TV']/parent::a"));
                fireTv.click();
                WebElement amazonPrime =new WebDriverWait(driver, Duration.ofSeconds(5))
                       .until(ExpectedConditions.elementToBeClickable(By.xpath("//a[text()='Amazon Prime Video']")));
               /* Webelement.click is not working.........
                               amazonPrime.click();
                      */
                Actions actions=new Actions(driver);
                actions.moveToElement(amazonPrime).click().perform();
                Assert.assertTrue(driver.getTitle().contains("Amazon Prime Video"));
            }
        }

Please help me in clearing my concept on this...

answers.body:
Unsatisfying answer... The two behave differently because the code behind is different. A brief description is below along with links to the methods in source.

A regular click() is

public void click() {
    execute(DriverCommand.CLICK_ELEMENT(id));
}

which tells the browser to execute a click on the provided element using the W3C defined interface.

An Actions.click() is

public Actions click() {
    return clickInTicks(LEFT);
}

which calls clickInTicks()

private Actions clickInTicks(PointerInput.MouseButton button) {
    tick(getActivePointer().createPointerDown(button.asArg()));
    tick(getActivePointer().createPointerUp(button.asArg()));
    return this;
}

which simulates pressing and releasing the left mouse button.

Having said all of that... my guess is it's more of a timing issue than a click() vs. Actions.click() method. When I run your code 10 times, I get 10 different behaviors. Sometimes it works... sometimes the left nav bugs out and disappears... sometimes the left nav bugs out and is empty... and so on. Without writing a LOT of extra code to detect site errors and starting over, it's going to be near impossible to make this script work perfectly consistently.

Some feedback on your code...

  1. Don't mix implicit and explicit waits (e.g., WebDriverWait). It can cause unpredictable wait times. See the docs.

  2. Simon Stewart, the Selenium lead, gave a talk at Selenium conf where he said don't use implicit waits. This is just one example of discouraging implicit waits, there are many more. The best practice is to use WebDriverWaits and wait for the desired conditions... clickable, visible, etc.

  3. Make sure you look around the desired element for IDs or other better/simpler locators, e.g. your locator for the hamburger is

    By.xpath("//i[@class='hm-icon nav-sprite']")

    but if you look at the A tag right above that I tag, you will see that it has an ID so the better, simpler, more stable locator here is

    By.id("nav-hamburger-menu")

  4. There's no point in using Thread.Sleep() instead of WebDriverWait. Thread.Sleep() should only be used as a last resort when the page is misbehaving and you can't find a viable WebDriverWait condition that works.

Taking all this feedback into account, the updated code would look something like this...

import java.time.Duration;

import org.testng.Assert;
import org.openqa.selenium.By;
import org.openqa.selenium.WebDriver;
import org.openqa.selenium.chrome.ChromeDriver;
import org.openqa.selenium.support.ui.ExpectedConditions;
import org.openqa.selenium.support.ui.WebDriverWait;

...

String url = "https://www.amazon.in";
driver = new ChromeDriver();
driver.manage().window().maximize();
driver.get(url);

WebDriverWait wait = new WebDriverWait(driver, Duration.ofSeconds(10));
wait.until(ExpectedConditions.elementToBeClickable(By.id("nav-hamburger-menu"))).click();
wait.until(ExpectedConditions.elementToBeClickable(By.xpath("//a[.='Fire TV']"))).click();
wait.until(ExpectedConditions.elementToBeClickable(By.xpath("//a[text()='Amazon Prime Video']"))).click();
Assert.assertTrue(driver.getTitle().contains("Amazon Prime Video"));

The problem is that when you run this code, sometimes you run into an ElementClickInterceptedException because the hamburger menu doesn't open and navigate quickly enough. To take care of this, we can build a custom click method that traps and handles some common exceptions.

import java.time.Duration;
import java.time.LocalDateTime;

import org.openqa.selenium.By;
import org.openqa.selenium.ElementClickInterceptedException;
import org.openqa.selenium.StaleElementReferenceException;
import org.openqa.selenium.support.ui.ExpectedConditions;
import org.openqa.selenium.support.ui.WebDriverWait;

...

public void click(By locator, Integer timeOutInSeconds) throws Exception {
    LocalDateTime expire = LocalDateTime.now().plusSeconds(timeOutInSeconds);
    while (LocalDateTime.now().isBefore(expire)) {
        try {
            new WebDriverWait(driver, Duration.ofSeconds(timeOutInSeconds)).until(ExpectedConditions.elementToBeClickable(locator)).click();

            return;
        } catch (ElementClickInterceptedException | StaleElementReferenceException e) {
            // do nothing, loop again
        }
    }

    throw new Exception(String.format("Not able to click element <%s> within {%s}s.", locator, timeOutInSeconds));
}

This code waits for the element to be clickable using WebDriverWait but handles ElementClickInterceptedExceptions and StaleElementReferenceExceptions by just trying again but exits once the timeout is exceeded.

Updating the original code to use this newly created method, we get

String url = "https://www.amazon.in";
driver = new ChromeDriver();
driver.manage().window().maximize();
driver.get(url);

click(By.id("nav-hamburger-menu"), 10);
click(By.xpath("//a[.='Fire TV']"), 10);
click(By.xpath("//a[text()='Amazon Prime Video']"), 10);
Assert.assertTrue(driver.getTitle().contains("Amazon Prime Video"));

which works... most of the time.

import org.openqa.selenium.By;
import org.openqa.selenium.WebDriver;
import org.openqa.selenium.WebElement;
import org.openqa.selenium.edge.EdgeDriver;
import org.openqa.selenium.interactions.Actions;
import org.openqa.selenium.support.ui.ExpectedConditions;
import org.openqa.selenium.support.ui.WebDriverWait;
import org.testng.Assert;
import org.testng.annotations.Test;

import java.time.Duration;

public class AmazonWebPageActions {

    WebDriver driver = new EdgeDriver();

    @Test
    public void testingMini() throws InterruptedException {
        // Setup
        driver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(Duration.ofSeconds(10));
        driver.manage().window().maximize();
        driver.get("https://www.amazon.in/");

        // Step 1: Click Hamburger Menu
        driver.findElement(By.xpath("//i[@class='hm-icon nav-sprite']")).click();

        // Step 2: Click on 'Fire TV'
        WebDriverWait wait = new WebDriverWait(driver, Duration.ofSeconds(10));
        WebElement fireTv = wait.until(ExpectedConditions.elementToBeClickable(
                By.xpath("//div[text()='Fire TV']/parent::a")));
        fireTv.click();

        // Step 3: Click on 'Amazon Prime Video' using Actions class
        WebElement amazonPrime = wait.until(ExpectedConditions.visibilityOfElementLocated(
                By.xpath("//a[normalize-space()='Amazon Prime Video']")));

        Actions actions = new Actions(driver);
        actions.moveToElement(amazonPrime).click().perform();

        // Step 4: Validate the navigation
        Assert.assertTrue(driver.getTitle().toLowerCase().contains("prime video"), "Title doesn't contain 'Prime Video'");

        // Optional: Close the browser after test
        driver.quit();
    }
}

question_comments.body: try/catch the .click() to see what exception is thrown there... the element click method will automatically scroll the element into view before clicking.  It will also do some checks that an Actions method would not.  The exception will tell you more.  For the linktext quirk I think it does a little more by finding rendered text nodes and performing a trim.  The xpath's text() method should be pretty similar but it will separate different text nodes methinks and won't trim spaces.
@SedJ601 While I have to agree your linked question is the same as this one, the accepted answer isn't terribly good. It includes guesses of how things work and the links are dead.

This question is similar to: Selenium webdriver click vs action.click whats the difference?. If you believe it’s different, please edit the question, make it clear how it’s different and/or how the answers on that question are not helpful for your problem.

79692886.body: you should not mix implicit and explicit waits... it can lead to unpredictable behavior.
While this code may answer the question, please edit your answer to also include some context, explaining how it works and when to use it. Code-only answers are not useful in the long run.

79693422.body: You can accept the answer and upvote it later. For your additional question, I won't be able to give an answer without more information. You should start a new question with this new info. Make sure you add all the details including code used, full error messages, etc. to your new question.

Sure !...Actually I am new and unable to upvote rightnow will upvote once able to do so..I have one query ..As per your suggestion I just used explicit wait for each element then clicked on each using Actions click it passed 90/100 times..but same code just replaced Action's click to Webelement.click()..It failed 10/10 timed. What is your thought on this?
If this or any other answer was useful please upvote it. Once you find the answer to your question, please mark it as accepted so the question isn't left unanswered.
! Thanks a lot for the inputs you have given. Great answer!!
